page.title: 16ECOLOGY
page.content: The area is rich in flora and fauna. Before the war cowslips were common but now they are rare, as are oxslips, wild daffodils and early purple orchids. Snowdrops, primroses, bluebells are however still plentiful and many garden flowers such as fritillaries and daffodils have become naturalised. Lichens and all kinds of fungi are common and in some of the woods rare orchids can be found. Three of the old dew ponds have been filled in which has diminished the numbers of dragonflies frogs and toads. All the large native mammals are regularly sighted with the exception of the otter and the small mammals are also present. Bird life is rich, recently the kingfisher has been sighted again and although barn owls are rare, they are in the area. There is also a report of a red squirrel in the valley
